history.title: History
history.caption: Legend has it that the idea for The Rink was inspired by a Depression-era skate salesman who demonstrated his product by skating on the frozen water of the Rockefeller Center fountain. However the idea came about, The Rink was the perfect fit for the sunken plaza, which was struggling to attract shoppers as the entrance to the high-end retailers in the underground concourse. The Rink, or “skating pond” as it was first known, officially opened on Christmas Day 1936. Originally planned as a temporary exhibit, The Rink was so popular it became a permanent addition, with the Prometheus Statue and the Christmas Tree providing one of the most familiar backdrops in the world.

cards.title: Dec. 1931
cards.caption: The First Tree—Depression-era construction workers decorated a small 20-foot tree with strings of cranberries and garlands of paper on Christmas Eve, Dec. 24, 1931, marking the beginning of the annual festive tradition.

cards.title: Dec. 1932
cards.caption: Center Theatre Opens––Center Theatre, a 3,500-seat performance space, opens on the southeast corner of 49th Street and Sixth Avenue. Site of popular “Icetravaganza” skating shows, it’s the only building from the original Rockefeller Center plan that has been torn down.
The Original Plan—the sunken plaza prior to the development of the “skating pond” in late 1936, featuring entrance ways into the concourse shopping areas.

Rink Construction, Opening Day, & Two Trees—the “skating pond,” as it was officially called upon opening, was first made available to the public on Christmas Day, 1936, and featured two Christmas Trees.
Sonja Henie & the “Icestravaganzas”—Norwegian figure skater and film star Sonja Henie would entertain onlookers in the 1930s and ’40s. She was also featured in the Center Theatre’s “icetravaganzas.”
cards.didYouKnow: The Rink features in the NBC shows taped at 30 Rock—having made cameos on Saturday Night Live's Christmas shows and during NBC News’ coverage of past presidential elections.

cards.caption: A Seal Named Sharkey—the famous trained seal, Sharkey,  appeared as the guest of honor at The Rink at Rockefeller Center with the Specialty Dancing Girls who are wearing roller skates instead of ice skates.
cards.didYouKnow: Sharkey, the trained seal, appeared alongside Jack Haley, Marta Eggert and Shirley Ross in the musical comedy “Higher and Higher” at the Shubert Theatre in August 1940.

cards.title: Jan. 1956
cards.caption: Tourists and locals celebrate the beginning of 1956 in this overhead photograph of The Rink and Tree on New Years Day, 1956.
cards.didYouKnow: In 1959, writer Truman Capote was shown getting some ice time in the pages of LIFE Magazine.

cards.caption: The Kennedys & A Good Cause—beginning in 1965 Senator Robert F. Kennedy and his wife Ethel held an annual skating party at Rockefeller Center at which 120 children were invited to join them on the famous outdoor rink.
cards.didYouKnow: The children that were guests at the Kennedy’s skating parties were from Brooklyn’s Bedford-Stuyvesent neighborhood.

cards.caption: The End of the Cold War—Through the 1980s, visitors continued to flock to The Rink, even in an uncertain world. A little less than a year after this photo was taken, the Berlin Wall was torn down.

image.alt: The End of the Cold War

cards.caption: The Rink & Tuba Christmas—Over 500 tuba players perform at the 24th annual Tuba Christmas play in front of the beautiful red Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree.

The Tallest Tree Ever—donated by Cathy and Jim Thomson, and hailing from Killingworth, Connecticut, this enormous Norway Spruce was the tallest Christmas Tree ever at Rockefeller Center, standing at 100 ft.
cards.didYouKnow: While heights vary, the average size of The Rock Center Christmas Tree is between 80–100 feet, and is almost always a Norway Spruce.

cards.caption: Olympians—Harlem students with Sochi Olympic dancing gold medalists Meryl Davis and Charlie White, the first Americans to ever win the title.
cards.didYouKnow: Many other Olympians have glided across The Rink’s ice, such as Kristi Yamaguchi, Scott Hamilton, Sarah Hughes, and Eileen Seigh.
